logic0intro: The AND function returns TRUE if all arguments are true; returns FALSE if any argument is false
logic0example: AND({Chinese}>90, {Math}>90, {English}>90), returns true if all three scores are >90, otherwise returns false
logic1intro: The OR function returns TRUE if any argument is true; returns FALSE if all arguments are false
logic1example: OR({Chinese}>90, {Math}>90, {English}>90), returns true if any score is >90, otherwise returns false
logic2intro: The TRUE function returns the logical value TRUE
logic3intro: The FALSE function returns the logical value FALSE
logic4intro: The IF function tests a condition and returns one value if true, another if false
logic4example: IF({Chinese}>60, 'Pass', 'Fail'), returns 'Pass' when Chinese score >60, otherwise returns 'Fail'
logic5intro: The IFS function checks multiple conditions and returns a value corresponding to the first TRUE condition
logic5example: IFS({Chinese}>90, 'Excellent', {Chinese}>80, 'Good', {Chinese}>=60, 'Pass', {Chinese}<60, 'Fail'), returns evaluation based on score
logic6intro: The NOT function returns the opposite of the given logical value
logic6example: NOT({Chinese}>60), returns false if Chinese score is >60, otherwise returns true
logic7intro: The XOR function returns the exclusive OR of all arguments
logic7example: XOR({Chinese}>90, {Math}>90), returns false if both scores are >90 or both are <90; returns true if exactly one score is >90
logic8intro: The ISEMPTY function checks if a value is empty text, empty object, or empty array
math0intro: The ABS function returns the absolute value of a number
math0example: ABS(-8) returns 8, which is the absolute value of -8
math1intro: The AVERAGE function returns the arithmetic mean of the arguments
math1example: AVERAGE({Chinese}, {Math}, {English}) returns the average score of three subjects
math2intro: The COUNT function counts the number of items
math2example: COUNT(John, Tom, Mike, Lisa) returns 4, which is the number of people
math3intro: The FIXED function rounds a number to specified decimals and returns text
math4intro: The INT function returns the integer part of a number
math4example: INT(3.1415) returns 3, the integer part of 3.1415
math5intro: The LOG function returns the logarithm of a number with the specified base
math5example: LOG(100, 10) returns 2, which is the logarithm of 100 with base 10
math6intro: The MOD function returns the remainder after division
math6example: MOD(4, 3) returns 1, which is the remainder of 4/3
math7intro: The MAX function returns the largest value in a set of values
math7example: MAX({Chinese}, {Math}, {English}) returns the highest score among three subjects
math8intro: The MIN function returns the smallest value in a set of values
math8example: MIN({Chinese},{Math},{English}) returns the lowest score among three subjects
math9intro: The POWER function returns a number raised to a power
math10intro: The PRODUCT function multiplies all the numbers given as arguments
math10example: PRODUCT({Price}, {Quantity}) returns total price, which is price multiplied by quantity
math11intro: The SQRT function returns the positive square root of a number
math11example: SQRT(9) returns 3, which is the square root of 9
math12intro: The SUM function adds all the numbers specified as arguments
math12example: SUM({Chinese}, {Math}, {English}) returns the total score of three subjects
math13intro: The SUMPRODUCT function multiplies corresponding components and returns the sum of those products
math14intro: The RANDOM function returns a random number between 0 and 1
date0intro: The DATE function converts a timestamp to a date object
date1intro: The DAY function returns the day of the month for a given date
date2intro: The DAYS function returns the number of days between two dates
date3intro: The DATEDIF function calculates the difference between two dates in years, months, days, hours, minutes, or seconds
date3example: DATEDIF({OrderTime}, {PaymentTime}, 'h'), if order time is 9:00 and payment time is 10:30 same day, returns 1.5 hours
date4intro: The DATEDELTA function adds or subtracts a specified number of days to a date
date5intro: The HOUR function returns the hour of a timestamp
date6intro: The MONTH function returns the month of a date
date7intro: The MINUTE function returns the minute of a timestamp
date8intro: The NOW function returns the current date and time
date9intro: The SECOND function returns the seconds of a timestamp
date10intro: The TODAY function returns today's date
date11intro: The YEAR function returns the year of a date
text0intro: The CONCATENATE function joins several text strings into one text string
text1intro: The EXACT function compares two text strings and returns TRUE if they are exactly the same, FALSE otherwise
text1example: EXACT({Phone}, {WinningNumber}), returns true if they match, false if they don't
text2intro: The LEFT function returns the specified number of characters from the start of a text string
text2example: LEFT('Class 3B Jay Chou', 2) returns 'Cl', the first 2 characters
text3intro: The LEN function returns the number of characters in a text string
text3example: LEN('Morning sun') returns 11, as there are 11 characters including space
text4intro: The LOWER function converts text to lowercase
text5intro: The RIGHT function returns the specified number of characters from the end of a text string
text5example: RIGHT('Class 3B Jay Chou', 3) returns 'hou', the last 3 characters
text6intro: The TRIM function removes leading and trailing spaces from text
text6example: TRIM('   Lanzhuo Industrial Internet   ') returns 'Lanzhuo Industrial Internet'
text7intro: The UPPER function converts text to uppercase
text8intro: The TEXT function converts a number to text
text9intro: The VALUE function converts text to number
aboutus.overview: {appTitle} is a cutting-edge platform developed and maintained by the open-source community, designed to revolutionize data management and application development through its unique concept of Unified Namespace (UNS).
aboutus.overview2: {appTitle} product actively promotes the concept of "Unified namespace" (UNS), which aims to enable data to be fully utilized and maximized in a variety of application scenarios through centralized data management.

account.passwordSame: The old and new passwords cannot be the same!
account.addRoleMax: Limit the creation of a maximum of 10 roles
advancedUse.overview: We have enhanced our software with additional permissions to provide greater flexibility and control for developers, enabling more effective integration and customization of solutions. While this increase in capability offers significant benefits, it also demands careful management to ensure optimal performance and user experience.

global.tip1Text1: Customize route configuration menus, refine permission management, and select icons.
global.tip2Text1: Create namespaces and leverage AI to generate apps.
global.tip3Text1: Import relational data and Modbus data to automatically generate workflows and dashboards.
global.tip4Text1: Monitor the status of MQTT brokers.
global.tip5Text1: View and debug GraphQL and PostgreSQL databases online.
global.tip6Text1: Realize code storage, CI/CD, and deployment.
home.guideText: This tour will guide you through the key features and functions we offer, ensuring you have a smooth and successful start.
home.guide1Text1: Homepage is the gateway to all system functions and applications.
home.guide1Text2: Click on the cards or icons to quickly access core modules.
home.guide2Text1: The navigation bar allows you to reach any {appTitle} page.
home.guide3Text3: User: View and edit the user information.
home.guide3Text6: Search: Search for the menu, and click the result for quick access.
home.guide4Text1: {appTitle} uses a primary menu + secondary menu structure for quick searching and switching.
home.guide5Text1: Proceed to the Data Modeling Guide for more insights on organizing and structuring your data effectively.

uns.guideVideo2Info: This is where you connect real-world data into your digital workspace.
uns.namespaceTooltip: Topic prefix /file path that groups related files (e.g. /factory/line1 ).
uns.aliasTooltip: Auto-generated as <file-name>-<UUID> (e.g.press01-temp-b8f8c7d2). Globally unique, doubles as the database table name. Read-only after save.
uns.dataTypeTooltip-Calculation: Combine attributes from any topic with custom expressions.
uns.dataTypeTooltip-Aggregation: Fuse two topics' JSON payloads into a single JSON array.
uns.dataTypeTooltip-Reference: Quoting other timeSeries or relational topic.
uns.attributeGenerationMethodTooltip-Rev: Auto-detect fields & types from a JSON sample or an existing DB table.
uns.keyTooltip: Click + to add attributes, - to remove.
uns.labelTooltip: Single tag value to help you group or search files (e.g. production , test ).
uns.mockDataTooltip: Flip on a pre-built Node-RED flow that publishes sample messages to this topic. Configure details in Node-RED later.
uns.autoDashboardTooltip: Generate a starter Grafana dashboard wired to this file's data.
uns.persistenceTooltip: Store every MOTT message in the backing database table (Alias). Supports retention & indexing.
uns.variablePickerTooltip: Select a topic field to turn into a variable. Click + to add more.
uns.variableChipsTooltip: By making the selected topic field a variable, it is free to click on it and use it.
uns.expressionTooltip: Write math, logic, or string ops here. Use variable names exactly as shown above.Example: avg(Variable1,Variable2)*60.
uns.functionCalculatorTooltip: Browse ready-made functions and insert them with one click.
uns.frequencyTooltip: Choose how often to run the aggregation (e.g. 1 s, 3 min, 6 hour).
uns.aggregationTargetTooltip: Select two or more source files (instances) whose JSON payloads will be merged into an array.
uns.timeReferenceTooltip: Select a file to reference its quality code and timestamp.
